text: A lone palm tree rises up into a yellow afternoon sky.  B it, the sparkling blue of the Pacific Ocean and the city San Diego.  A dry, hot Southern California day.  Even the is lazy, and a little bored.

Santa Claus wears shorts and sandals, ringing a bell as h collects for the Salvation Army.  This is Christmas in th Southland.  No snow, no winter wonderland.  Just a pleasa thick heat and an unchanging season, as music continues. Turning the corner, walking into frame is ELAINE MILLER, She is a tall woman, consumed by the fevered conversation Having with her pale young son WILLIAM, late pre-teens. stand apart from the other shoppers.  All around them is highly-charged salesmanship of the season... silver glitt fake Christmas trees.  She hurries her son through the commercial juggernaut, continuing their lively intellectu conversation, when something stops her.  A Workman is aff letters to a store-front.  He has already placed the MERR now he's finishing the XMAS.  Elaine is strong, but alway pleasant, always clear about her purpose in this life.
Excuse me, I'm a teacher.  There is no word in The English Language -- "Xmas." It's either
Merry Christmas... or  Happy Holidays.
The Workman nods thanks, with faux appreciation, as Mom t away.  The Workman shares a look with William, who shrugs that's my Mom.

This is the new professional-class.  It's a mini-condo community.  Rows of Spanish-styled three-bedroom houses w common walls.   Move in on one of these homes, the one wi Christmas lights.  At the door is a furtive 15 year-old G She checks her cheek, straightens her hair.  She hides something under her coat, and gathers the proper nonchala to enter.  Music fades.

We now hear the dialogue between this lively Mother and h son, as she cooks a pan full of soy-based health-food cut The meal simmers unappetizingly in the pan.  Across the k we see William.  He's a great listener, with a calm and c face that takes everything in.
- so Livia -
-- killed everyone off so her son Tiberius could inherit the throne. (thoughtful pause) Just like Nixon.

William nods, intrigued.  He has a good disposition.  The world of knowledge engages him, and he loves what it brin out in his Mom.  There is a small clatter at the front do as the girl we've just seen enters, barely brushing some She silently curses herself. ELAINE (cont'd) Anita, is that you?
Hey Mom!  I already ate.
Mom moves to the living room to greet William's sister. peers into the next room.
She's almost to her bedroom down the hall when mom catche her.  We now discover ANITA, 16, up-close.  She is an all young Natalie Wood, with a suspicious and sunny smile.
You sure?  I'm making soy cutlets.
The words "soy cutlets" sends a small shiver through the
I'm fine.  Already ate.
William stands in the doorway now, watching, monitoring, Mom moves closer to his sister.  She sees something curio about her daughter.
Wait.  You've been kissing.
(too quickly) No I haven't.
(peering at her lips) Yes... yes, you have...
No I haven't.
Yes you have.  I can tell.
(boldly) You can't tell.
Mom steps closer and examines the lips even more carefull To her, everything is a quest for knowledge.
Not only can I
tell , I know who it is. It's Darryl.
Anita is stunned silent.  She turns slightly to look at h in a hall mirror, searching for clues, implicating hersel immediately. ELAINE (cont'd) And what have you got under your coat?
This is the booty Anita didn't want to give up.  Mom pick the corner of an album cover now visible under her jacket She withdraws the album. It's Simon and Garfunkel's  Bookends.
(busted) It's unfair that we can't listen to our music!
(weary of the issue) Honey, it's all about drugs and promiscuous sex.
Simon and Garfunkel is poetry!
Yes it's poetry.  It's the poetry of drugs and
promiscuous sex. Look at the picture on the cover...
Mom's fingers at the edges.  We examine the insolent face Richard Avedon's classic album cover.  Even Simon and Gar look guilty under her scholarly inspection. ELAINE (cont'd) ... honey, they're on
pot.
First it was butter, then sugar and white flour. (beat) Bacon. Eggs, bologna, rock and roll, motorcycles.
Nearby, William squirms as he watches the gently escalati conversation.  Anita glances at her brother.  He silently urges her to downshift.  She can't. ANITA (cont'd)
Then it was celebrating Christmas on a day in September When you knew it wouldn't be "commercialized."
That was an experiment.  But I understand -
What else are you going to ban?
Honey, you want to rebel against knowledge. ELAINE (cont'd) I'm trying to give you the Cliff's Notes on how to live in this world.
(simple and direct) We're like nobody else I know.
These are the words that sting Mom most.
I'm a teacher.  Why can't I teach my own kids? (pats chest)
Use me.
Darryl says you use knowledge to keep me down.  He says I'm a "yes" person and you're trying to raise us in a "no" environment!
(immediately, can't help it) Well, clearly, "no" is a word Darryl doesn't hear much.
Anita gasps.  Ever the peacemaker, William weighs in.  Ne is a poster - "No More War."
Mom --
Everything I say is wrong.
I can't live here!  I hate you!
Even William hates you!
I don't hate her.
(to William) You don't even know the truth!
William looks vaguely confused.
Sweetheart, don't be a drama queen.
Anita takes a breath and then out of her mouth comes the strangled-sounding words of a kid swearing at her parent the first time.
Feck you!  All of you!
Hey!
Anita runs down the hall to her room.  Elaine turns to Wi relating to him more as a fellow parent than a child. ELAINE (cont'd) Well, there it is.  Your sister using the "f" word.
I think she said
"feck."
(sputtering)
What's the difference?
(encouraging) Well.  The letter "u"...
Shot moves in on the kid, as we hear the opening strains The Moody Blues' "Nights in White Satin."

Music continues.  Shot moves along a row of very mature-l male teenagers, examining themselves in the bathroom mirr There's the kid with a very mature-looking moustache, the proudly sporting full-blown hormonal acne (he slaps on so Hai Karate ), the guy to whom puberty has already delivered the face of an adult, complete with long jutting sideburns... then a blank space at the mirror, as the shot moves down, down to find William.  He is so much younger, without a z sight.  Puberty is so very distant on his horizon.

Song continues as we see William's perspective of these m older looking kids.  Girls now are visible, and they are more mature than the boys we've just seen.  They flirt an glow, arms trailing across the shoulders of the boys. Whispering in each other's ears, none of them looking dow It's a troubling experience, to be this close to the allu world of older teenagers... and to be so invisible to the
Are you
really in our grade?
(louder) Are you really in our grade?

William turns to see tall, adenoidal TIM TOBIN.  The most looking kid we've seen yet, he challenges William in a lo theatrical tone.  It is a voice right out of  Guys and Dolls, which incidentally is the school play in which Tobin had starred.  William answers in a respectful voice.  He is desperate for acceptance.
Yeah.
Hey guys!  Check it out!  William doesn't have any
pubes
Others now begin to gather around, examining William.  He never been more naked.
How old are you man?
He's not a man, he's a little baby kid.  He Doesn't even get zits yet.
How come you don't have any hair down there?
(in loud, funny voice)
Where are your pubes???!! Their voices echo off the tiled walls.  Now everyone is w the hairless William.  He is confused by their meanness.
Yeah.  Where are your

pubes? All eyes are on him, waiting for a response.  The kid's m wheels turn frantically.  And from somewhere comes an att a swagger, and somehow the perfect line arrives from what only be a merciful deity.
(cool, dismissive) I had 'em.

I shaved 'em off. It is a new persona for the kid -- the witty guy.  And it Guy #2 cracks up, then others.  William's new accuser is suddenly surrounded by the impressed gales of laughter of older boys.  Others turn away, on to other things.  Tobin at William, and then also turns away.
William jumps into the backseat of the white Ford Country station wagon, carrying books.  ("See ya pubes!")  Mom co driving William and Anita home from school.
(cheerfully, by rote, to William in back) Put on your seatbelt.   I don't want you flying through the windshield.
Anita examines her own un-fastened seatbelt, which Mom ha noticed.
We got our annuals today --
(cheerful, automatic) "Received" your annual.
(looking at his photo) I look so much
younger than everyone else.
Enjoy it while you can.
Camera drifts from Mom to Anita, who can take it no longe
Mom.  It's
time.
(pleasant, pointed) Can this wait until we get home?
Mom,
pull over. Tell him the truth. Tell him how old he is. Mom pulls over, and stares straight ahead with deep irrit
(as in "be quiet") He
knows how old he is.
The other kids make fun of him because of How young he looks.  Nobody
includes him.
They call him "The Narc" behind his back...
They do?
What's a "Narc?"
(bleeding for her brother)
A Narcotics Officer!
Well what's wrong with that?
(ever the peacemaker) Come on you guys.  It's no big deal. I'm 12.  It's okay. She skipped me a grade, it's okay.  Big deal.   I'm a year younger.  They're 13, I'm 12 -- (beat) Aren't I?
Their silence is eloquent.
(confessing, in a rush) I also put you in first grade when you were five and never told you.
(trembling) So...  I'm... how old?
A heavy quiet.  She and his sister ignore him, as they no debate the subject with each other.
You lied to him!  You make such a big deal about the truth and you lied!
(that one hurts) He never asked.
What -- like he's going to ask if he's as old as he
thinks he is?  Don't you realize, this is going to scar him
forever?
Honey... sweetheart... don't be Cleopatra.  We have to be his mother
and his Dad.
You put too much pressure on him!
(apprehensive) How... old...
And when he rebels in some strange and odd way, don't blame me.
... am I?
(matter of fact) I skipped you an extra grade.  You're eleven.
(horrified, voice crackling)
He looks at his body, the information affects him physica New sounds come from way down deep inside.  Mom now begin speed-rapping, trying to stem the leak.  She starts the c

So you skipped fifth grade.  There's too  much padding In the grades.  I taught elementary school.  5th grade - unnecessary.  Nothing happens in the 5th grade.  All Teachers know it, no one talks about it.
(still in shock) E -
leven.
And you skipped kindergarten because I taught it to you when you were four.
(still horrified, looking at his body) This explains... so much...
You've robbed him of an adolescence!
Adolescence is a marketing tool.
He's got no "crowd"... no friends...
Okay!
Anita reaches out to her brother.  With the compassion of saint, she offers this:
Honey, I know you were expecting puberty.  You're just going to have to shine it on for a while.
Deeply embarrassed, William shrinks down in the seat.  Mo monitors his face constantly.  She is raw and sincere... yes, inspiring:

Who needs a "crowd?"  You're unique.  You're two years ahead of everybody.  Take those extra years and do what you want.  Go to Europe for a year!  Take a look around, see what you like!  Follow your dream! You'll
still be the youngest lawyer in the country.  Your own great grandfather practiced law until he was 93.  Your dad was so proud of you.  He knew you were a
pronominally accelerated child.
What about me?
(heartbroken, can't help herself) You're rebellious and ungrateful of my love.
Well, somebody's gotta be normal around here!
(blinking, still can't believe it)
Eleven.

William finishes the last of many candy bars.  A mound of wrappers sit just below the mirror.  He examines his face hopefully for zits.  Nothing coming.  We begin to hear Si and Garfunkel's "America."
Anita stands in the living room.   The song continues pla on the stereo.
I want to play you a song that explains why I'm leaving, and try to listen.
We can't talk?  We have to listen to rock music?

William watches sadly.  Anita's good-looking boyfriend DA a dead ringer for young Stephen Stills, loads her suitcas into a large turqouise Chevy.  The suitcases are adorned plastic stick-on flowers.    All coolness is leaving Will life.  Mom watches nearby, worried and helpless.   (Their is more austere, less "fun" than the other front lawns.)
Take good care of her in San Francisco, man.
Darryl gives the kid a sub-human look.  He's invisible, t young to converse with.
How can she leave such a loving family?
Anita turns and heads towards them.  She focuses on Willi placing her hands on his young shoulders.  Her face is ve close to him now, as she delivers this sage prediction of future.
One day you'll be cool.
He nods stoically, hopefully.  He is utterly lost.  She l forward and whispers in his ear. ANITA (cont'd) Look under your bed.  It'll set you free.
Anita shakes hands with Mom, and exits.  As the car takes
She'll be back.
In the distance we hear the whoop of her daughter.
YEAHHHHH-HOOOOOOOO.
Maybe not soon...
William watches wistfully.  He moves away from his mother She pulls him closer.  Shot moves in on his slightly fear face.
Anita looks back at the receding American Gothic-image of mother and brother.  Sister waves to brother.  She feels him.  Music now shifts to The Who's "Sparks."

William locks the door.  He reaches under his bed.  It's black leatherette travel bag, with tartan design.  He unz the bag -- it's filled with albums.  He flips through the amazing, subversive cache of music.  Cream's  Wheels of Fire... the seminal Bob Dylan bootleg  Great White Wonder... the Rolling Stones'  Get Yer Ya Ya's Out... The Beach Boys'  Pet Sounds... Abraxas by Santana... Jethro Tull's  Stand Up... The Mother's of Invention's  We're Only In It For The Money...  Led Zeppelin... Crosby, Stills and Nash... Miles Davis'  Bitches Brew... and The Who's  Tommy... with a note taped to it.
"Listen to
Tommy with a candle burning and you will see your entire future..."
The heady effect of all these albums registers, as we see lighting a candle.
A blue school notebook, with ballpoint pen renderings of names of groups like the Who and Led Zeppelin, complete w carefully drawn thunderbolts.  Also, the name LESTER BANG
William, now 15, sits in class with book,  Adventures in Journalism. His hair is shoulder-length.  A dedicated teacher, PATRICIA DEEGAN, walks the aisles.  Music continues.
William presses the food machine button, pulls an orange a vending container.  He still looks younger than most of students... and these days, especially the girls.
William sits apart from all the others, under a tree.  He intently, happily, as he eats the orange.  It's a copy of Creem Magazine.  Music continues.

Camera moves across the photos, catching the expressions fashions of the rock heroes of the day.  Ian Anderson of Tull, eyes wide and hair flying as he plays flute.  Neil enigmatic with perfectly patched Levis.  The Southern Roc of The Allman Brothers Band, posing and laughing in front massive stacks of amps.  Marc Bolan of T. Rex, his ringle backlit by stage lights.  David Bowie in skin-tight Japan piece attire, onstage with The Spiders From Mars.  Pete T of the Who, slashing windmill-style at his guitar. Drift down to a by-line -  by Lester Bangs.

William walks through the parking lot after school.  Ever now congregates around the new arrival of their lives - t own cars.  Arms suddenly clap William on the back, friend faces smile strangely, laughing.  He takes a few steps an looks up to see... a school official is hurriedly removin something from the high-school marquee.
which reads: WILLIAM MILLER IS TOO YOUNG TO DRIVE (OR FUC All are laughing.  He laughs with them, and turns as his goes slack.  He shrugs, marches on.

The song we've been listening to is ripped off the turnta a highly-active man in a red promotional t-shirt proclaim greatness of The Guess Who.  He is a ferocious, lumbering driven presence, and he fills this small radio studio to very brim.  This is LESTER BANGS, 25, the rarely-seen God then new art-form -- Rock Journalism.  A Disc-jockey with long hair watches helplessly.  William views all this thr glass window.  He stands on the corner of a downtown side street, halfway up a steep incline.  He is the only perso the streets this early Saturday morning.  Reveal that he watching a live radio show, audible to us through the sma p.a. speaker overhead.
Quite an honor to have the World's Greatest Rock Critic... and editor of
Creem Magazine, back Home in San Diego for a few days -- Lester Bangs.
What is this hippie station?!  Where's Iggy Pop?  Don't you have a copy of
Raw Power?!
Lester, isn't it a little early for this?
Bangs searches for the album -- vinyl flying everywhere n with no regard for album jackets.
Found it!!

William watches intently.  Bangs thuds the needle onto a of  Raw Power. We're rewarded with a blast of Iggy and the Stooges' "Search and Destroy."   A closer shot on William watching the whirlwind of anarchy inside.  Lester does an Pop impression, acting out a story for the d.j. that we c hear, never noticing the kid soaking in everything from t other side of this double-glass window.

Bangs walks with William on this sharply inclined San Die street.  It's early, the streets are silent.  Bangs is ab fifteen beer pounds overweight.  His jeans are loose, his paleness and messy moustache an emblem of the long days a nights spent writing.  In there somewhere is a good-looki guy.  His hands are thrust deeply into his pockets, and h takes big sweeping steps.
So you're the one who's been sending me those articles from your school newspaper -
I've been doing some stuff for a local underground paper, too.
What are you like the star of your school?
They hate me.
You'll meet them all again on their long journey to the middle.
The kid nods, they walk. BANGS (cont'd) Well, your writing is damn good.  It's just a shame you missed out on rock and roll.
I did?
Oh yeah.  It's over.
Over?
Over.  You got here just in time for the death rattle, the last gasp, the last
grope.
Well.  At least I'm here for that.
Bangs looks at the much smaller kid, shaking his head.  I too late for newcomers.  But if the kid's age is an issue doesn't mention it.  Like a machine-gun:
What do you type on?
Smith-Corona Galaxis Deluxe.
You like the new Lou Reed?
(automatic) The early stuff.  The new stuff, he's trying to be Bowie, he should be himself.  I'm not a big Lou man.
Yeah, but if Bowie's doing Lou, and Lou's Doing Bowie, Lou's still doing Lou.
(standing his ground)
If you like Lou.
Take drugs?
No.
Smart kid.  I used to do speed and sometimes Nyquil and stay up all night writing and writing, like 25 pages of dribble about, you know, the Guess Who, or Coltrane,
just to write, you know, with the music blasting...

Me too. The writing part... For a moment, the serious demeanor dissolves and the odde thing happens.  Bangs laughs.  It's an odd and charming l the kind a tough guy keeps well-hidden.  It surprised the who smiles back.  Bangs stops at the corner, and offers a pleasant but very final nod of the head.
Well, alright.  It's been nice to meet you.  I'll see you around.  Keep sending me your stuff.
Okay.  See you.
I can't stand here all day talking to my many fans.
But neither have anywhere to go on this early downtown mo They stand for a beat, hands in pockets, on this deserted street.  They are alone together, there's nobody else in
William listens intently as Lester eat a sandwich.  His f is an open book filling with words.
-- so anyway, you're from San Diego and
that's good. Because once you go to L.A., you're gonna have friends like crazy but they'll be
fake friends, they're gonna try to
corrupt you.  The publicists!  The bands!  You got an honest face, they're gonna tell you
everything. But you CANNOT make friends with the rock stars.
The kid takes out a green collegiate notebook and gesture can I make a note? Bangs nods. BANGS (cont'd)
Cannot make friends with the rock stars. (savage bite) That's what's important.  If you're a rock journalist, a true journalist -- first you will never get paid much.  But you
will get free records from the record company.

The kid's eyes widen.  Bangs, in direct conflict with his writing style, is looking suspiciously like a compassiona softie. BANGS (cont'd) And they'll buy you drinks, you'll meet girls... they'll try to fly you places for free.... offer you drugs...  I know.  It sounds great.  But
they are not your friends.
These are people who want you to write sanctimonious stories about the genius of the rock stars and they will
ruin rock and roll and strangle everything we love about it.
Privately, William thrills.   We.  Our. It all sounds great to him.  He listens to the grouping of the words, every one them.  He madly scribbles. BANGS (cont'd) They are trying to
buy respectability for a form that is
gloriously and righteously -
The kid leans forward as Lester finds the right word. BANGS (cont'd) -
dumb! And you're smart enough to know that.  And the day it ceases to be dumb is the day it ceases to be
real. Right?  And then it will just Become an
Industry of Cool.
... Industry... of... cool...
And

that's what they want! And it's happening right now.  I'm telling you, you're coming along at a very dangerous time for rock and roll.  The war is over.  They won.  99% of what passes for rock now... SILENCE is much more compelling.  It's over.  I think you should turn around and go back and be... a lawyer or something... but I can see from your face that you won't. I can pay you thirty-five bucks.  Gimme a thousand words on Black Sabbath.
(attempting cool) An assignment.
Yeah.  And you should build your reputation on being honest... and
unmerciful.
(writing in notebook) Honest...
unmerciful...
And if you get into a jam -- call me. I stay up late.

Bangs reaches across the table, and William watches as he scribbles his number on the back of the kid's green colle notebook.  The notebook has just become valuable.  They s together, listening to the beautiful and compelling silen

Mom drives William to the San Diego Sports Arena.  She lo out the window at the adrenalized concert-goers.  She fee protective not just of her son, but an entire generation. William goes over his questions for Black Sabbath.
Look at this.  An entire generation of Cinderellas and
there's no slipper coming.
William looks out the window at the sign: TONIGHT - SOLD BLACK SABBATH with special guest Stillwater.
You can drop me off here.
Black.  Sabbath.  Just remember - you wanted to be Atticus Finch in
To Kill a Mockingbird.
The kid doesn't answer.  He silently goes over his questi ELAINE (cont'd) As long as I know this is just a hobby, I'll go along with it.
All I have to do is
listen. That's what Lester Bangs said.
(dryly) I'll be waiting right here at eleven 'o clock sharp.  If you get lost, use the family whistle.

He unhooks his seatbelt, stuffs his questions into an ora canvas shoulder-bag and exits. Elaine watches her son disappearing into the stony rock-c crowd.  It's a windy night.  Everything about this image troubles her.  She fights with herself, and then uses the whistle immediately.  He turns. ELAINE (cont'd) (sweetly, too loud)
Don't take drugs!! Fifteen concert-goers turn around instinctively, at the s of a Mother, and then identify William as the object of h concern.  All around him, we hear:
Don't take drugs!! He winces, nods and moves forward.  Music echoes from the windows of many other cars.

location: SAN DIEGO SPORTS ARENA BACKSTAGE RAMP

text: The kid tromps down the steep incline leading to a small backstage arena door.  He rings the buzzer.  The door whe open to reveal the keeper of the San Diego Sports Arena's backstage list.  Famous to all those who attempt to enter this is SCOTTY.  He is a wiry, humorless man for whom powerlessness is the theme of his life -- except for thos hours he controls the list.  Scotty is only forty but eve about him screams that he's an angry sixty.
Hi.  I'm William Miller and I'm here from
Creem Magazine to interview the band Black Sabbath.
Scotty, immediately suspicious, moves to a nearby podium snaps through three clipboard pages.  He moves back to th door and grabs the handle.
Not on the list.

He shuts the door with finality.  The kid stands silently a moment.  He looks over his shoulder, at two chattering Groupies watching his dilemma from the top of the ramp. look at him sympathetically, but he turns away.  William the buzzer again, withdrawing a copy of  Creem from his bag. The door opens.
Sir, I'm a journalist, and here's a copy of the magazine.
The magazine hangs in mid-air.
You're
not on the list. Go to the top of the ramp with the girls!

Slam.  William stands there for a moment.  Unsure of what do next, he looks back to the top of the ramp.  Rejected him just moments earlier, the groupies now feign disinter Bracing himself, William rings again.  The door opens slo this time.  Scotty stands peering at him.
(in a rush)
What-happens-after-I-go-to-the-top-of- the-ramp with-the-gi -
Slam.  Lock.

William inches into the realm of the girls at the top of ramp.  The wind whips.  It's just him, and two Groupies i their evening best.  They now pretend to barely notice th young journalist who has been banished to stand with them Chattering excitedly, with sophistication far beyond her years, is ESTRELLA.  She sports long unruly black hair. partner hangs in the shadows, adjusting shoes.  Estrella to the kid with great disinterest.
Who are
you with?
(embarrassed to be alive) Me?  I'm with myself.
No, who are you
with? What  band?
I'm here to interview Black Sabbath. (beat) I'm a journalist.  I'm not a... you know...

Estrella stares at him.  Moving into the parking lot ligh introducing herself, is a luminous girl in a green faux-f trimmed coat.  This is PENNY LANE.  There is an inviting and real interest in the way she asks:
... you're not a
what?
(enthralled) Oh... I'm just... not a... you know.
Not a "what"?
(charmed) You know.  A "groupie."
The two girls are deeply insulted by the word.
Ohhh!
Sorry, I -
We.  Are not.  "Groupies."
Estrella indicates Penny with great reverence.
This is
Penny Lane, man.  Show some respect.
-- sorry.
Penny steps closer, focusing completely on the kid.  Behi her, concert-goers throw a few woo-woos their way.  She s not to hear them.
"Groupies" sleep with rock stars because they want to be near someone famous. We are here because of the
music. We are
Band Aids.
She used to run a school for Band Aids.
We don't have
intercourse with these guys.  We support the
music. We  inspire the
music. We are here because of the music.
William is nodding like a doll in a dashboard window. Listening.
Marc Bolan broke her heart, man.  It's famous.
It's a long story.  I'm retired now. I'm just visiting friends.
She was the one who changed everything. She said "no more sex, no more exploiting our bodies and hearts... "
Right.  Right.
"... just blow-jobs, and
that's it.
Okay.  Well, see, now I get the difference.

Shot drifts off him and picks up, out of the darkness, an breathless girl teetering on tall shoes.  She is in the v of 16.  Her black hair is cropped short and died red, jus like the cover of Bowie's  Aladdin Sane. She is POLEXIA, the voluptuous one, from Riverside.
(the usual greeting) It's all happening.  It's all happening.
Polexia!!   Did you tell Sabbath we were going to be here?
I talked to Dick with Stillwater, I talked with Sabbath.  They're all dying to see us.   It's all happening.
This is our journalist friend. Journalist Friend, meet Estrella Starr, and Polexia Aphrodisia. And you are --
William.
Silent beat.  His name lands like a thud.
Here comes Sabbath!
Ozzy!!!  Tony!!!  It's us!!

A long black limo with darkened windows swishes past, bee twice.  The metal backstage gate rises and the limo rolls inside.  And then silence again.  The girls do not discus being rebuffed. ESTRELLA (cont'd) I think I saw Sapphire in there.
(can't hold it in any longer) Okay.  I was with Ian Hunter
all night at Rodney's Last night.  Wanna see his spoo?  I saved it in a baggie.
She opens her purse and shows the girls something inside. William edges away.
(peering into purse) I'm really happy he's doing so well.
(regarding what's in purse) Yeah.  I know he's such a talented guy.  I mean, look at him.  Who deserves it more?
(looking in purse) Nobody -- he's so sweet.
(with compassion) Don't you just
root for him, you know. To go
that little distance between good and great?
Wait.  That's not his.  I would know his.
A very odd look on his face, William now cranes for a dis look.   What's in that purse?

Crazy.

Beware

The kid listens intently, and makes notes. LESTER BANGS (cont'd) ... don't do it to make friends with people who are trying to use you to further the big business desire to glorify worthless rock stars like Stillwater.  And don't let those swill merchants re-write you.

Now. What are you listening to?
William knocks on the teacher's lounge door.  A Teacher a protective of their sanctuary.
(urgently) I need to talk to Mrs. Deegan, from Journalism.
Mrs. Deegan appears in the doorway.
The sun is still shining.  It's late afternoon, as Elaine exits her car and arrives home.  She sees a few extra car the driveway, is immediately suspicious.
Elaine arrives to find William, Mrs. Deegan and Darryl aw her in the living room.  It's a 1973-style intervention. wear sunny, compassionate smiles.
Whatever it is, the answer is no.
Elaine, we need to talk to you.
Nothing is wrong. I am a teacher. You're a teacher.  We speak the same language.
Mom sits down.  She is fully engaged and worried, her nat state. MRS. DEEGAN (cont'd) Now I'm not a jump-up-and-down person, but something
wondrous has happened to William.  And you have every reason to be happy... (knows her) ... and calm.

Carefully gauging Elaine's face, the teacher continues. MRS. DEEGAN (cont'd) William has been gifted with a shining opportunity in the world of journalism. Through a love of music, and at an oddly-young age, he has received a major assignment from a national publication called

Rolling Stone Magazine. Mrs. Deegan produces a copy, and places it on Elaine's la It sits there like the plague. MRS. DEEGAN (cont'd) Now you are rather famously not a fan of rock music, but such are the ironies of life, that happens to be the very topic of William's assignment - (cheerfully) - rock music.  A band.
(warily, to Darryl) Honey, what are
you doing here?
Moral support.
Mom looks evenly at her son, seated opposite her in this living room.
What's involved?
Well.  It's a great opportunity.  He'll be well-paid, and published nationally -- (quickly) -- and he'll go on tour with a rock band for four days.  No small planes... he travels on a bus.
Is it time for me to say something?
Sure.
No.
And in anticipation of that response -
No.
-- William has prepared --
(rueful) "Lo, that which I have feared has come upon me."
(lightening fast) "He who jealously guards his fears, quietly yearns to bring them about!"
Mrs. Deegan admires their high-strung intellectual parryi makes an impressed noise.
(with compassion)

No. I have raised him to be an honor student, which he is.  We have agreed on all our goals.  We raised him to be a lawyer, we moved here to be near the finest law school in the West.  Plus, he has finals coming up, and in one week he graduates with
all his friends -
He's got no friends!!
Darryl.  Please.
Nearby, having anticipated all of the above, William nods Mrs. Deegan, and stands.
Elaine, may I present to you... your own son.
William takes a lawyerly stroll, turns to face his mom.
Lady of the Jury. (beat) I wish to disprove the prevailing false belief that rock music is based on drugs and sex.  True, perhaps at one time... but rock music is different now.  It is
now performed by hard-working intellectuals, with... with blazing intellectual pursuits, and I am going to play for you a piece of music designed to show you that my thesis is correct.
This is going to be hell.
Across the room, Darryl takes his position near the stere
The song is based on the literature of Tolkien...  and it's mystical attempt to elevate humanity has been successful throughout the world...
this song will change your life.

Mom stifles a cough.  William nods to Darryl, who reveren drops the needle with a thud.  Mom is trapped, as we list silent static... and then... the opening notes of Led Zep "Stairway to Heaven."  William gives his Mother the album cover's inner-sleeve with lyrics. WILLIAM (cont'd) We ask you only to listen.

Mom's face remains stoic to the bitter end.  ("...  and she's buying the Stairway to Heaven." )  The song ends.  Silence. All look to Elaine.  They wait on her response.  We hear turntable arm return to its cradle.
What am I supposed to say?   You say it's Tolkien, fine.  They sound like nice kids.  Is it meant to elevate humanity?  "Sure, let's elevate humanity.

"  All I have is my honesty.  That's what I believe, and that's what I know. (flipping through magazine) Oh.  Here's a nice ad.
She holds up the magazine.  And ad reads, in large bold t BUY THIS FUCKING ALBUM. ELAINE (cont'd) You've clearly ganged up on me, and I still say no.  No no no no no no no.

(very professional) Russell.   Do you think we might be able to find some time to talk when we get to Phoenix?  I want to interview everyone separately... and I felt we'd start with you and me.

He didn't even realize he was thirsty, but he is.  He nod thanks to Penny, the perfect road companion for all.  And Penny gives the other Coke, her Coke, to William.  He acc it too, and starts back to his seat.  He's been blown off he knows it, but before he exits Penny grabs his arm and whispers in his ear:
I may need to stay in your room tonight. Russell's in a bad mood.  He's very
Bob Dylan in Don't Look Back today. He's trying to write.
William nods cooly -- they are comrades -- and returns to seat.  A large joint passes in front of him, across him, Polexia, as everyone cheers Doris the Bus rumbling up ano hill.
(inhaling deeply) Want some?
No thanks.
A wall of pot smoke is exhaled, right into his face.  It surrounds him like a cloud.   The bus shudders, as Russel continues playing slide up ahead.
Elaine sits in her living room, filled with her books.  L Department store photos of her children on the wall.  She her own loneliness, and his too, as she dials a phone num
Has William Miller arrived yet?  He hasn't.  Could you give him a message as soon as you see him? -

Several hours later on this ride.  Outside, night and des Inside, a few cigarettes, a joint of two glow in the dark of the bus.  The end of the Led Zeppelin classic "Whole L Love" plays from the bus stereo, full blast.  Everybody i free and anonymous in the dark.  They sing at full-volume William looks out the window in wonder.

All enter the lobby like warriors, in a pack.  The hotel are spotted with curious hangers-on, decked out and loung Dick is already stationed, as always, at the front desk. sad state of hotel service grates on a road dog like Dick is forever teaching others their jobs.
Jeff, Tony... Keys... keys... keys... room list... (re: luggage, to hotel bellman) If it doesn't have a number on it, it ain't ours!

He gives key and a stack of messages to Russell, and turn William who he makes feel more important.  Penny is nearb her suitcase and tackle box purse.  William watches Russe guitars whisked away - they are luggage-numbered 1, 3, an DICK (cont'd) The Enemy! William cooly takes the folded message, doesn't look at i and tries to pretend this embarrassing moment didn't happ Jeff exchanges a look with Russell. who approaches William.

Rolling Stone. Don't forget the Rules.  This little shit is the Enemy. He writes what he sees. (beat) But it would be cool to be on the cover.

Plus our girlfriends read this magazine and - (looking at Band-aids) -- you know.

Penny speaks confidentially to him.  If she is slightly b it is only because she's good at logistics, emotional and otherwise.

Can Sapphire stay in your room tonight? She had a big fight with Ozzy, and Polexia's not working out with Jeff Bebe. (to Sapphire and Polexia) You just have to remember... these guys are jealous, insecure, talented, egocentric, and manipulative geniuses... they're

lead-singers. They can say "I love you" to 20,000 people... but any fewer is a real problem. (girls nod, comforted, she continues to the kid) Jeff Bebe has so much jealousy over Russell that he can't express.  Plus, he never slept last night.   You keep Sapphire and I'll stay with Russell.
William covers his disappointment over losing Penny as a roommate.  Cooly:
Sure.  I'll take her.
Me too?
Sure.
Estrella arrives with travel bag, equally homeless, looki hopeful. WILLIAM (cont'd) If there's room -

Penny squeezes him.  He  feels cool... but the girl he really wanted to stay in his room now joins Russell, disappearin into the elevator.  He looks down at the message in his h and opens it. It reads: DON'T TAKE DRUGS!  He snaps it closed quickly, anyone can see. 59A   IN. RUSSELL's ROOM -- NIGHT Russell plays acoustic guitar, a notebook cradled on his Trying to write.  It's coming slowly.  Shot moves off him past a flickering television, onto Penny who silently and intently watches Russell as if he's a rare and beautiful He looks over at her - she turns away quickly.  He goes b to work.  Tries to catch her watching him again.  She tur away just in time.

Stillwater's "Fever Dog" plays from the t.v. radio.   Wil on the bed, a thick local phone book on his lap.   His hotel room.  He watches self-consciously as the girls go about ritual of inhabiting a room on the road.  Sapphire flutte paisley scarf over the room lamp.  Polexia puts a towel a the crack of the door, blows out the glowing embers on to many sticks of incense, and moves to the phone.  Estrella joined them as well, complete with a bag full of shoes. Instantly, we have atmosphere and not much room left in t the smallest room in the hotel.   William thumbs through phone book with fascination.
All these people. (wondrous, off phone book) And they all live in
Phoenix.
(on phone) Hi Dad!!  I can't talk long!  I'm here in Paris.  I'm staying in another Youth Hostel with no phone and no address for mail!!
(still wondrous, from phone book) Alex.
Lowbatz.
(emerging from bathroom) I was the one who told him what to tattoo on his fingers, I was the one who made his shirts... I was
there when his wife left him.
Charles.  C.
Swoop.
(on phone) I CAN SEE THE EIFFELL TOWER.  DO YOU KNOW THERE ARE 578 STEPS TO THE TOP?
She's reading from a European tour book.
Paul and Debbie
Finger.
(looking out window) Oh my God.  Simon Kirke of Bad Company is
by the pool. The girls mobilize by the window.  William is increasingl aware that he is an outsider in his own tiny room.  He tr to organize his stuff in the corner.
I GOTTA GO!  I'LL CALL FROM ROME!
Is anybody here as worried about Penny and Russell as I am?
(the perfect daughter) AND HAPPY BIRTHDAY TO MAGGIE!! I LOVE YOU!!
She winks at William, who looks away.
(to Polexia and William) Ooo, watch out - whoever you look at when you say that - that's who you really mean.
Polexia hands up and throws a pillow at Sapphire,  the ki watches these girls like a tennis match.
Russell puts down his guitar.
You know.  We should talk about what we don't talk about.
We don't have to.
No, I - I went to Catholic school.  I believe in guilt and... you know, if there's any to be had, I pretty much want to roll around in it.
I don't believe in attachments.  No boundaries.  Just the music.
I'm just saying, it's okay to talk about it.
Penny stands and turns.  She speaks the word.
Leslie.
Russell nods.  The name is out in the open. PENNY (cont'd) Leslie.  Leslie.  Leslie.  Leslie. Leslie.  Leslie.  Leslie.  Leslie.
(somehow satisfied) Alright - now we're talking.
But she continues, saying the name in a multitude of diff ways, in different accents, and with different degrees of indifference and passion and lust and play-acting and moc drama.
As he listens and studies this ethereal creature for mean Is she mocking him?   In love with him?  Taunting him?  S him?
Leslie.  Leslie.  Leslie.  Lesssssslie. Leslie.  Leslie.  Leslie.  Leslie. Leslie.  Leslie.  Leslie.  Leslie. LESlie.  Leslie...
She continues saying it until it no longer has meaning. finally she sits next to him. PENNY (cont'd) (beat) Now.  Have I helped you get that off your chest?
They kiss.
The girls continue their settling-in process.
Opie, can I order room service?
The nickname "Opie" re-opens a nagging wound.  Polexia ha up, and begins to dial again.
Okay.  You guys.  Wait.   Put down the phone, Polexia. (she does, sadly) First, this is my room...
Come on, you're a fan like us.  You're on
our side of the line.
Second.  I'm not Opie.  Alright?  Opie is a little boy.  I'm here to do a job.  I am a
professional.
(flipping luggage tag) Ooooooo, sorry, Mr.
Third! (has their attention now) ... this phone is a big, big deal.  In a minute, I have to go interview Russell.  Do
not answer this phone if it rings.  I have family members with
severe anxiety Problems.  She  will not understand.
(wounded) But what if
Ozzy calls Sapphire?   And I gave Jimmy Page this number.
Or a guy who
looked like Jimmy Page. William looks at their troubled faces, full of too much-l and too much make-up.
Okay.   I have a solution.  Answer the phone.  But if anyone
without an English accent is on the phone... (winging it) Just hang up.  Or say it's the wrong room.
They nod.  It's a good plan.

SHOULD I COME BY LATER?
A group of golf conventioneers are now trapped behind the cart.  They ease past William as he negotiates with Russe through the door.
YES, I'M IN TOO TRUTHFUL A MOOD!
MAYBE THAT'S A GOOD THING!!
I'LL SEE YOU AT THE RADIO INTERVIEW LATER!!  TEN-THIRTY IN THE LOBBY.
OKAY!
GO AWAY!
OKAY!
We hear Penny's giggle.  Then the door opens, and it's Pe looking ravishing.  In the background, Russell sits shirt at the table.  He playfully pelts the kid with crumpled u wads of hotel stationery.
Don't worry.  Some to the radio interview.
No, I'm fine.  I'll just interview Jeff Bebe some more.
(as in "you're on of us") GO AWAY!

He can't help but listen to the muffled of laughter, just for a moment, escalating.  He flips the over: HOUSEKEEPING PLEASE ENTER - CLEAN ROOM.

The guitar of Russell Hammond.   "Fever Dog"...  The band is Stillwater. (beat) Watch with your mind as they materialize.

William's room.

Night Circus. The band scoots closer to the microphone, ready to talk. continues, looking meaningfully at the band.  They are waiting... eager for a chance to speak. QUINCE (cont'd) Every minute a baby is born

Well... not to get into a "me" thing... this is Jeff talking... but I did start the band, some time, actually, ago. This is back when we were the Jeff Bebe band, and I placed an ad in a magazine called
Peaches looking for a guitarist and Russell Hammond answered.

(with deep understanding) Peaches.
Jeff watches Quince's head lower.  It's hard to know when talk with Quince.  The depth of his mellowness is tough t in rhythm with.

He instantly realizes he's slipped, on the air. RUSSELL (cont'd) Ooops.  Better hit the delay button.

All eyes turn to Quince, whose head stays down, grooving some inner beat.  He says nothing.  The band looks at eac other.  We become increasingly aware that Quince may now asleep.  Long silence.  William shares an amazed look wit Penny.  Quince is definitely asleep.  Russell leans forwa and continues talking quietly, with hilarious sincerity. RUSSELL (cont'd) Okay - we're talking now, right?  Why the fuck do you wait until and interview in Arizona to say something nice about me.  Why don't you say it to my fucking face sometime?  Because I tell you every time I think you nailed something.
Everybody pays you compliments.  It's not my fucking job to kiss your fucking ass all the time.
Well then who's fucking job is it? Because my ass is dying for a kiss. And I know yours is too.

smegma. Penny covers her mouth as offers a look of absurdity to W He offers one back, as laughs are stifled throughout the William shares a look.  Quince is still deeply asleep, as usually quiet tony leans forward to speak.
Feces.

Adrenalized laughter.  The whole band is crammed into a m sized rental car.  Penny half on William's lap, half on Russell's.
(to William) See, this is what
nobody writes about! The in-between times!   This!  Us! Right now!!

The phone is ringing.  Estrella emerges from the bathroom no make-up and a t-shirt.  She picks up the phone.  Acros room, Sapphire signs for room service.  Now she is far to made-up.  The t.v. radio plays Free's "Fire and Water" in b.g.

(cringing) I thought you were English.
Could you please give him a message? Could you tell him to
call home immediately?

I know what's going on.
Alright.  Okay.  But I'm just going to say this, and I'm going to stand by it. (can't help herself) You should be really proud of him. 'Cause

I know guys... and I'll bet you do too.  And he respects women, and he likes women, and let's just pause and appreciate a man like that.   You created him out of thin air, and you raised him right, and we're all looking out for him.  And that's more than I've ever said to my own parents, so there you go. Russell and William sit in two large red-leatherette seat the hotel lobby.  William shuffles through many pages of questions written in small script.  His tape recorder mic sits balanced on the chair.
(very professional) Now that you're starting to be successful, you had twenty-six years to write your first Album... and you'll have maybe
four months for the second. Do you worry that the pressure of the business will get in the way of the original joy of making your music?  Or -
Russell blinks.  The all-consuming issues of his life are in front of him.
Whoa! (laughing) I need three more beers and my guitar before I can answer that question. Let's take a walk.

Russell walks the outskirts of the pool area with William William follows him through the sliding glass door to his facing the pool.  Russell grabs his guitar.  They stand f moment, unheard by the others, and regard the living port twenty yards in front of them.  The off-limits after-hour pool area has been overtaken by the Stillwater tour membe Jeff Bebe sits in a chair nearby.  Dick laughs at a joke. Always the life of the party, Penny Lane dispenses stolen from a maid cart.  And she is the first to slip into the for some after-hours, against-the-rules swimming.  Effort she turns a collection of people into a party.  They rega her, well out of earshot of the others.
For a minute I thought you were actually a real journalist... which is... you know, it's great. (beat) Shut that thing off, and I'll tell you the truth.
